data.text: Contents
Introduction

Catering hospitality is a service provided by the Catering Department for ad-hoc service requests which include beverages (Tea / coffee/ milk and cold drinks), light refreshments, finger food, hot food, fruit and other snacks.
Typical events that may require catering hospitality may include (but not limited to):
VIP visits
Open days
Training days
Critical Incidents

Hospitality should only be used for special events as described above and not for day to day meetings and local celebrations. All requests for hospitality must be approved by the Division's senior management team.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
To provide arrangements for authorising and requesting catering hospitality services.
To provide an auditable mechanism of ad-hoc hospitality requests
To identify a controlled cost effective and authorised service etc.
Definitions

table_items.text: Provision of food and drink for specific events
Where hospitality is not funded by the Trust but funded privately

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
EFM Governance Board is responsible for reviewing the findings from monthly audits of EFM service including catering services.
Director of Operations (Estates and Facilities) is responsible for the management and delivery of the catering services.

Site Catering Managers is responsible for the day to day operational delivery of the catering services and overseeing requests for hospitality, ensuring a process is in place that only enables authorised requests for hospitality to be processed.
Division Senior Managers are responsible for:
Delegating authority for expenditure on hospitality catering by providing list of managers authorised to approve bookings where necessary
Ensuring expenditure is incurred against approved hospitality budgets in accordance with SFIs.
Ensuring all staff working within their areas of responsibility are aware of and follow Trust policy on hospitality.
Budget Holders are responsible for
Monitoring booking approvals, costs and appropriateness of hospitality requests within their areas of responsibility and carry out appropriate actions to rectify anomalies.
All Staff are responsible for ensuring:
They are aware of the Trust's hospitality policy and its contents.

That the provision of catering hospitality services at any meeting, event or function is not automatically requested and is only done so with the correct level of authorisation from the relevant budget owner.
General principles

The provision of catering hospitality services at any meeting, event or function should not be looked upon as an automatic requirement and should only be requested when the correct level of authorisation (Budget Owner) has been approved.

The cost of ad-hoc catering services will be charged on a monthly basis to individual Directorate budget codes and it is the responsibility of the Associate Director or delegated senior managers to monitor hospitality processes within their respective departments.

Late cancellation of catering services will result in the application of a cancellation charge to the service or department who made the booking depending on notice given, in accordance with the details set out in section

Hospitality services may be provided to external organisations that hold meetings on Trust premises. An account will be issued by the catering provider for such provision and should be paid directly to them.

Hospitality procured via a third party should only be through approved suppliers. This is to ensure that the Trust doesn't buy in food from unregulated suppliers where we are unable to provide assurance around food hygiene standards, food providence, compliance with allergens regulations etc.  in accordance with Food Safety policy
Catering provision and eligibility
As a minimum, catering services are available during the hours of 08:30 to 17:00 on a daily basis, Monday to Friday and at other times required by the Trust.
Summary criteria for hospitality provision include:
Hot/Cold beverages can be provided for organised meetings. Beverages should only be provided for meetings which span across the period between 09:00 -15:00.

Working lunches and teas can be ordered for meetings when the only or most suitable time is lunchtime or when to hold the meeting at another time would unduly disrupt clinical activity. While lunchtime meetings are necessary at times we should actively discourage the use of this time for meetings.

Hospitality can only be provided once the booking form on the hospital website has been fully completed including budget cost code, venue, date, time, quantities, menu choice etc. and submitted following approval by authorised signatory.
Directorates who have not allocated any of their budgets to the hospitality budget code cannot request hospitality.
Hospitality for retirement presentations will be provided in accordance with the Personnel Policy on Recognition of Long Service or Outstanding Achievement.
Christmas / New Year buffets should be funded from ward/department Trust Funds or General Purpose Trust Funds as allocated by the Finance Directorate.
During black alert/critical incident sandwiches and cold drinks may be provided on the day for staff that are unable to be released from a

ward/clinical dept. for meal breaks. Completed booking form (including budget cost code, area, date, time, quantities, etc. and submitted following approval by authorised signatory) must be submitted to Catering Department. Availability will depend on site activities and notice given.
How to order

Requests for the provision of hospitality should be made to the service provider at the time of booking the venue and generally with a minimum of 48 hours' notice for beverages, 5 working days for hot/cold buffets and special menus.
To order hospitality refreshment, please contact the relevant site Catering department.
All bookings via the catering services department must clearly identify the budget cost centre that will be recharged for payment of services.

Hospitality booked via private caterers should be booked directly and purchase orders raised in accordance with the Trust's standing financial instructions. Hospitality procured via a third party should only be through approved suppliers.

Should there be any changes prior to your meeting or function or should you wish to cancel your booking, please notify the relevant site Catering department. Short notice cancellations may incur a cancellation charge as outlined in section 9.
Additional charges
There will additional charges for:
a) Functions required out of normal hours i.e. after 4.00pm, weekends or Bank holidays
b) Functions delivered to areas not within the confines of the hospital
c) Any equipment i.e. platters, flasks etc. removed from the venue without the prior consent of the Catering Manager- charge will be made to booking cost centre.
Cancellation charges
Late cancellation of catering services will result in the application of a cancellation charge to the service/department that made the booking depending on notice period given as outlined below:

data.text: Payment of functions
Trust recharge functions
Trust hospitality is chargeable to a Directorate hospitality budget cost centre as approved by an authorised signatory.
On completion of your function the Catering department will arrange for the appropriate amount to be charged to the approved cost centre by the Finance Department.
Southend: a copy of your original order will be provided to nominated EFM Contracts manager to validate against invoice.
Private functions
A function classified as a private Function if it is not eligible to be charged to a Trust budget cost centre.
These functions will be paid for by a Department's private fund or by an individual or a Company.
Private caterers

Where hospitality is being provided by an external company to the Trust's catering services, the order must be made via the Trust ordering system in accordance with the Trust's Standing Financial Instructions. Orders must not be made without a purchase order number.
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the EFM Governance Board, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policy and procedure guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the EFM Governance Board the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
